facts.text: Suit filed by appellant Kunju Kesavan to redeem Otti created by Bhagavathi Parameswaran in favour of Krishnan Marthandan on 5.5.1091 M.E. for 3500 fanams.

holdings.text: The certificate granted by the High Court was properly granted as the market value of the property exceeded Rs.10,000 at relevant times and plaint valuation at redemption price does not bind for appeal purposes.

anchor.surface_text: But in those cases in which the plaint is not required to be valued in this way, a question may arise as to the proper value of the claim both in the court of first instance and on appeal to this Court. The word indirectly in such cases covers the real value of the claim which is required to be determined quite apart from the valuation given in the plaint. In this case, the High Court found the value to be Rs. 42,000 and Rs. 80,000 at the two material times. It is obvious that the plaintiff was not required to value his plaint on the real or market value of the property but on the price for redemption. He was not, therefore, concluded by the valuation given in the plaint. He had asked for possession of the property after redemption, and that property as the High Court has found, is well above the mark in value. The certificate was, therefore, properly granted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Two valuation tests satisfied using market value of subject-matter on appeal and indirectly in suit; redemption suits valued at mortgage amount, not market value; approbation principle inapplicable.

holdings.text: The trial court had jurisdiction as suit was properly valued and laid there; jurisdictional objection not entertainable at this stage.

anchor.surface_text: The attack on the jurisdiction of the court of first instance must also fail. The suit as valued was properly laid in the court of first instance, and in any case, such an objection cannot be entertained now. The preliminary objection is, therefore, rejected.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plaint valuation governs pecuniary jurisdiction; no timely objection raised.

holdings.text: Exh. III evinces contrary intention under s.32 of Ezhava Act; makkathayam property not divisible equally among wife and children but taken exclusively by wife.

anchor.surface_text: If one goes by the document, Exh. III, it is clear that there was such an intention implicit in it. The donor gave some properties to his wife, and others to his grandson. His son was then unheard of for years. He thus divided his properties between his wife and grandson and the intention is manifest that each was to take exclusively.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Document divides properties exclusively between wife and grandson; no rule of impartibility presumed; s.32 allows contrary intention for exclusive taking.

anchor.surface_text: But in those cases in which the plaint is not required to be valued in this way, a question may arise as to the proper value of the claim both in the court of first instance and on appeal to this Court. The word indirectly in such cases covers the real value of the claim which is required to be determined quite apart from the valuation given in the plaint. In this case, the High Court found the value to be Rs. 42,000 and Rs. 80,000 at the two material times. It is obvious that the plaintiff was not required to value his plaint on the real or market value of the property but on the price for redemption. He was not, therefore, concluded by the valuation given in the plaint. He had asked for possession of the property after redemption, and that property as the High Court has found, is well above the mark in value. The certificate was, therefore, properly granted.
In our opinion, therefore, the High Court was right in holding that the present appellant was number entitled to redeem the otti, having never enjoyed the jenmom rights.
